title: Introduction to IMO Conventions and Codes
headline: This free online course explains the development of international conventions and the requirements for a flag state.
description: Safety at sea is paramount. This course introduces you to the International Maritime Organization (IMO) conventions and codes and teaches the IMO’s structure, roles and function. Investigate the process for developing international conventions, flag state requirements and the roles of the flag state. Compare the differences between a flag state and a port state, some committees of IMO and the functions of IMO sub-committees.
courseDescription:
The International Maritime Organization (IMO) is a specialised agency of the United Nations  and it governs marine conventions and codes. The establishment of the IMO coincided with a period of rapid change in the global shipping industry. The course teaches you about the main focus of the IMO and its function, structure and roles. We explain the brief history of the IMO and its various committees and subcommittees. This course will analyse the IMO Bulk Liquid and Gases (BLG) and Flag State Implementation (FSI) as well as The Radio Communications and Search and Rescue (COMSAR). In addition, we will outline the roles of the Stability and Load Lines and Fishing Vessel Safety (SLF) and Standards of Training and Watchkeeping (STW) and examine the technical problems faced by the IMO.

This course then describes the IMO conventions like the International Conventions for the Safety of Life at Sea 1974 (SOLAS), the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL 73/78) and the Helsinki Convention. We introduce you to the international conventions on load lines 1996 and the international regulations for preventing collision at sea, amongst others. The course highlights the objectives for these conventions and some of their technical provisions. We explain the codes used at sea and the comprehensive set of measures used to enhance the security of ships and port facilities. Study the perceived threats to ships and port facilities in the wake of the 9/11 attacks in the United States. We identify the three security levels: ‘normal’, ‘heightened’ and ‘exceptional’, along with each level’s state measures. 

Familiarise yourself with a ship owner’s responsibility under the ISPS, Continuous Synopsis Record (CSR) and the Ship Security Alert System (SSAS). Investigate the declaration of security, which should be completed before an interface starts between a vessel and a marine facility. Understand the convention for the control and management of ships ballast water and sediments and the methods used to treat ballast water. We explain the inspections carried out by the port state, along with how the feedback of deficiencies observed with the flag state is shared. We highlight some schemes like the Voluntary IMO Member State Audit Scheme and how it provides audited member states. You will learn about a comprehensive and objective assessment of how effectively key IMO conventions are administered and implemented. With the aid of a diagram, this course illustrates how the IMO, flag state, port state and recognised organisations collectively implement the IMO conventions. This course will notably interest students, researchers and anyone curious about IMO conventions and their operations. So register for this course and begin your learning experience.

slides:
• Learning Outcomes 
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to;
    • Explain the Structure of the IMO
    • Distinguish between the Assembly and the council 
    • List the functions of the Council 
    • Outline the committees that carry out the technical work in the IMO 
    • Outline the role of the IMO 
    • Discuss the duties of flag state with respect to control, reduction and prevention of marine pollution
    • Distinguish between Flag State and Port State
    • Discuss the power and limitations of IMO
  • Introduction to International Conventions 
  • Shipping is an international business involving many littoral states that allow international trade happen through ocean transportation. The nations that are land-locked also depend on nearby ports in neighboring countries for their supply of cargo and commerce that may involve sending finished goods to other countries through the port located in a littoral state. 

    The maritime commerce has seen many wars toward keeping the trade routes open and the colonial powers could only expand their influences through commercial and naval powers. 

    After the world wars the nations of the world got united under the United Nations and the IMO and ILO and other treaties, conventions and international laws ushered in a new era of globalization; exchange of goods and services has been liberalized globally and it will be important for a ship manager to understand the importance of the International bodies in making that possible and ongoing.

  • Developing International Conventions
  • As a Superintendent, you should understand how international conventions are developed. Member States convert international conventions into national legislation which applies to ships flying their flag. 

    Failure to comply, whether willful or through improper understanding, can lead to functional loss and/or prosecution by Member State. You can safeguard against this with respect to your ships by being thoroughly conversant with the latest developments at IMO and ensuring compliance by your ship.

    In exercising responsibility for developing new conventions and ensuring the relevance of existing agreements, IMO has promoted the adoption of some 40 conventions and protocols, and adopted over 800 codes and recommendations concerning maritime safety, security, prevention of pollution and related matters.

    IMO has been able to appreciably reduce the time taken for the conventions to enter into force. Thus, concerns of the international community are transformed into a legal framework much faster. This can be seen in this comparison between the evolution of the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS) and the International Ship and Port Facility Security Code (ISPS).

    IMO has been able to appreciably reduce the time taken for the conventions to enter into force. Thus, concerns of the international community are transformed into a legal framework much faster. This can be seen in this comparison between the evolution of the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS) and the International Ship and Port Facility Security Code (ISPS).

  • Implementing International Conventions
  • IMO has no powers to enforce conventions
    IMO is not an enforcement body. Implementation of the requirements of a convention is mandatory on the Member States which are parties to it. Once a Member State has ratified a convention, it has to develop and implement national legislation in line with the convention. This legislation will apply to ships flying its flag.

    If a Member State has signed the convention "subject to ratification, acceptance or approval", it need not make rules in line with the convention. However, it is obliged to refrain from acts which are against the spirit of the convention.

    Vessels of a Member State, which is not a signatory to a convention, will not be given any preferential treatment when they visit ports in the other Member States. The Port States are empowered to inspect the ships as per the convention.

    Codes and recommendations, which are adopted by the IMO Assembly, may have non-mandatory sections that are not binding on the Member States. However, their content can be just as important, and in many cases, are implemented by the Member States through incorporation into domestic legislation.

  • Lesson Summary 
    • In IMO, the Assembly comprises of all Member States and meets once every two years. It may also meet in extraordinary session if necessary. 
    • The Assembly is responsible for electing the council and approving the organization's work program and budget for the next two years.
    • In IMO, the Council is elected by the Assembly for two-year terms, beginning after each regular session of the Assembly. In between Assembly sessions, the Council performs all functions of the organization. It normally meets twice a year. It monitors the progress made in achieving the plan objectives and key performance indicators. 
    • The functions of the council include:
      - Appointing the Secretary-General, subject to the approval of the Assembly
      - Coordinating the activities of the various Organizations of the IMO
      - Reviewing the draft work program and budget estimates.
    • One of the key duties of the IMO is to devise strategies and measures to keep the waterways clean by preventing marine pollution from ships

  • Learning Outcomes 
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain briefly the jurisdiction of SOLAS, MARPOL
    • Outline the importance of following codes: STCW, COLREG, Load Line, ISM Code and ISPS 
    • List the methods for exchanging ballast water 
    • Explain briefly Green House gases
    • Outline briefly the history of Helsinki Convention
    • Explain the features of ISM and ISPS codes.
  • Explaining Conventions and Codes
  • The scope of the IMO conventions and codes, which govern maritime safety, security and environment, is vast. You should understand the necessity of a convention or code, its contents and the related certification. 

    Often a penalty or detention can be directly traced to inadequate understanding of the certification requirements. 

    The Company is responsible for ensuring that adequate resources and shore-based support are provided to ensure that its vessels meet the requirements of these conventions and codes.

    IMO conventions fall into three main categories, maritime safety and security; marine pollution; and liability and compensation. Other conventions are concerned with areas such as dealing with facilitation, tonnage measurement, unlawful acts against shipping and salvage, etc.

    Often a penalty or detention can be directly traced to inadequate understanding of the certification requirements. 

    The Company is responsible for ensuring that adequate resources and shore-based support are provided to ensure that its vessels meet the requirements of these conventions and codes.

    IMO conventions fall into three main categories, maritime safety and security; marine pollution; and liability and compensation. Other conventions are concerned with areas such as dealing with facilitation, tonnage measurement, unlawful acts against shipping and salvage, etc.

  • Helsinki Convention
  • The 1974 Convention
    The original Helsinki Convention was signed in March 1974 by seven States bordering the Baltic Sea. The Convention entered into force in 1980. For the first time ever, all the sources of pollution around an entire sea were made subject to a single convention.

    The 1992 Convention
    A new convention was signed in 1992 by all the states bordering on the Baltic Sea, and the European Community. After ratification, the Convention entered into force on 17 January 2000. The Convention covers the whole of the Baltic Sea area and the member states are illustrated as below.

  • BWM 2004
  • International Convention for the Control and Management of Ships' Ballast Water and Sediments (BWM). Adoption: 13 February 2004; Entry into force: 12 months after ratification by 30 States, representing 35 per cent of world merchant shipping tonnage.

    Ballast water is taken is ship’s tanks to maintain the stability of the ship. This Ballast water which is taken from one coast of the world and discharged in another coast can introduce harmful aquatic organisms.

    The discharge of water from ballast tanks has been responsible for the introduction of species that cause damage to the environment and economy. Hence it is required to carry out ballast water exchange at deep-sea prior to an arrival port.

    The problem of invasive species is mainly due to the increase in trade and traffic volume over the last few decades. The effects in many areas of the world have been devastating.

    Specific examples include the introduction of the European zebra mussel in the Great Lakes between Canada and the United States, resulting in expenses of billions of dollars for pollution control and cleaning of fouled underwater structures and water pipes; and the introduction of the American comb jelly to the Black and Azov Seas, causing the near extinction of anchovy and sprat fisheries.

    Ballast water is taken is ship’s tanks to maintain the stability of the ship. This Ballast water which is taken from one coast of the world and discharged in another coast can introduce harmful aquatic organisms.

    The discharge of water from ballast tanks has been responsible for the introduction of species that cause damage to the environment and economy. Hence it is required to carry out ballast water exchange at deep-sea prior to an arrival port.

    The problem of invasive species is mainly due to the increase in trade and traffic volume over the last few decades. The effects in many areas of the world have been devastating.

    Specific examples include the introduction of the European zebra mussel in the Great Lakes between Canada and the United States, resulting in expenses of billions of dollars for pollution control and cleaning of fouled underwater structures and water pipes; and the introduction of the American comb jelly to the Black and Azov Seas, causing the near extinction of anchovy and sprat fisheries.

  • Lesson Summary 
    • The main objective of the SOLAS Convention is to specify minimum safety standards for ship construction, equipment and operations.
    • The MARPOL 73/78 Convention aims to prevent and minimize pollution from ships - both accidental and from routine operations. It is intended to deal with all forms of pollutions from ships, other than disposal of waste into the sea by dumping, which is addressed by another convention known as the London Dumping Convention.
    • The Ship Energy Efficiency Management Plan (SEEMP) incorporates best practices for the fuel-efficient operation of ships, such as better speed management throughout a ship's voyage.
    • The International Ship and Port Facility Security Code (ISPS Code) is a comprehensive set of measures to enhance the security of ships and port facilities.
    • The ISPS Code aims to reduce the vulnerability of the industry to attack, thus countering the threat and reducing the risk.
    • CSR provides an onboard record of the history of the ship. The CSR shall be issued by the administration. It contains the name of the ship, Flag State, the date of registry with that state, the ship's identification number, the port of registry.
    • SSAS is designed to raise an immediate alarm ashore in the event of security threats or security incidents by notifying the Flag State of the ship, without alerting ships or coastal states in the vicinity or giving any indication onboard.
